abstract:
250-word version:

Background: This study aimed to determine the failure rate of miniplates used in bone-anchored maxillary protraction (BAMP) treatment for skeletal Class III malocclusion and evaluate the influence of the surgeon's experience on the failure rate.

Methods: This retrospective study included patients who had miniplates placed for BAMP treatment between January 2010 and April 2020 at the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Diseases, Helsinki University Hospital, Finland. The study group consisted of 164 miniplates in 42 patients, divided into two groups based on the operator: surgical residents (Group 1) and consultant surgeons (Group 2). The primary outcome was the failure rate of miniplates, measured over the treatment duration.

Results: The overall failure rate of miniplates was 23.8% (39/164). The failure rate for Group 1 was 31.4% (27/86), while for Group 2, it was 15.3% (12/78) (p < 0.05). Out of all failed miniplates, 69.2% were placed by residents and 30.8% by consultants. No significant differences in failure rates were observed between genders or placement sites.

Interpretation: The failure rate of miniplates was significantly higher when placed by surgical residents compared to consultant surgeons, suggesting that surgical experience plays a crucial role in reducing failure rates. This highlights the need for careful supervision of residents during miniplate placement to improve outcomes.
